Subcategory: 2000-2020 Chains based on Numbers, Objects, Animals or Names
Variation Example: Chain tale or song about the wedding of a louse & a flea (other animals). Other animals (fly, frog, ant, beetle, newt, snake, rat, etc.) help with the preparations (come as guests, bridesmaids, musicians, baker, cook, etc.). Various complications ensue

A hen (rooster, cat, other animal, young woman) has a nut (cherry pit, a corn, etc.) stuck in her throat (dies in some other way). A rooster goes to get water for the hen to drink, but the water sends him to get red silk from a bride first. The bride sends him to get a wreath, etc. Or, the rooster asks for help from various animals (pig, cow, etc.), people (miller, baker, shoemaker, etc.), and/or objects (river, tree, etc.). When the rooster comes back with the water, the hen is already dead. All the animals participate in the funeral procession. At the end, a flea (fly, mouse) falls & is crushed under the wagon’s wheel. The rooster buries the hen & then dies from grief. (The hen who had been choking is bumped & the nut becomes dis-lodged from her throat.

Classifications: Rooster Strikes out the Hen's Eye with a Nut
Variation Example: A rooster throws a nut that strikes out a hen’s eye. He blames the hazelnut bush, because it tore his pants. The bush blames the goat for eating its leaves. The goat blames the herdsman who did not give him good pasture; the herdsman blames his master for not giving him enough to eat, etc.

Chain tale, game, song, or rhyme in which a small animal (chicken, flea, louse, other insect, small child, etc.) dies (falls into a cooking pot & is scalded, is burned, is drowned). Various people (girl, woman, father, etc.), animals, & objects (door, window, wagon, broom, tree, water, well, etc.) lament the death, which they announce in their characteristic manners. For example, the flea weeps, the tree loses its leaves, the door squeaks, the broom sweeps, the table “entables”, etc.

ll the wit-nesses show their grief at this misfortune. For example, the hen ruf-fles her feathers, the rubbish begins to burn, the stairs creak, the oak falls down, the magpie sprains his leg, the ox breaks his horns, the river flows with blood, the maidservant breaks her jug, the house-wife smears dough on the wall, etc. The master locks his wife up & the maidservant goes to look for people who are equally stupid, etc.

An ant (beetle, cockroach, grasshopper, snail, cat, etc.) finds some money, buys new clothes, & sits in her doorway. Many animals come by & ask her to mar-ry them, in their characteristic voices. The ant chooses the mouse, because he is quiet. When the mouse stirs the stew (wedding soup), he falls in the pot & drowns. When the ant discovers this, she weeps. The bird tears his own beak off, the seagull tears his own tail off, etc.

A rabbit borrows money from a beetle, a hen, a fox, a dog, a tiger, & a hunter. When the beetle asks for the money back, the rabbit tells him to wait behind to count the money. Instead, the hen eats the beetle, then the fox eats the hen, etc.

A pancake (pudding, cake, cookie, cabbage strudel, round bread) jumps out of the pan (plate) & runs away from the cook (mother) who wants to eat it. The pancake runs outside & meets a series of animals (hen, rooster, duck, goose, fox, pig) or people who also want to eat it. The pancake runs away from all of them, bragging about all the others it has already escaped from. The fox (pig) induces the pancake to come close by pretending to be deaf, & gobbles it up. The pig drops part of the pancake, so now all pigs root around in the mud looking for it.

Classifications: Devouring Animal That Was Cut Open
Variation Example: A cat (wolf, troll, mouse, giant, bear, chick, pump kin, woman, louse) with a huge appetite drinks a great quan-tity of milk, then eats a lot of food & devours the family with whom he lives. He goes out & people (animals) whom he meets on the road ask him why he is so fat (where he is going, why he is out so early). The cat lists everything he has eaten & announces that he will eat this person too. He devours everything he meets, e.g. certain animals, a cowherd, a flock of birds, a driver & his team of horses, etc.

This misc. type consists of various chain tales in which a person (animal) wants an animal (person, object) to do something (go home, pick pears, grow, get some beer, eat, reap grain). The animal refuses. The person threatens him by asking someone else (person, animal, object, or element: e.g. dog, stick, fire, water, butcher) for help. The request is not granted (the help is postponed until some demand can be met). Finally someone (hangman, angel of death, animal) obliges, & all the others in succession do what the person had wanted them to. In a few variants, a mouse eats cheese (wheat, wick of an eternal flame). A cat condemns the mouse & eats it as punishment; a dog eats the cat for eating the mouse. Each animal, object, or element is blamed for having damaged the one before it, & is then punished.

An ant (sparrow, hare) hurts himself on some ice, which he thinks must be the strongest thing in the world. The ice says this is not true, because the sun can melt it. The sun says it is not the strongest, because a cloud can obscure it. The cloud thinks a mountain is stronger. The mountain thinks grass or a mouse is stronger, the mouse thinks the cat is stronger, etc. (also fire, water, cattle, knive, butcher). The cat (rat, God, human) is finally the strongest, or the question remains undecided.

The Jewish bodyguards of the Persian king Darius discuss the question, what is the strongest thing in the world? The first thinks it is the king; the second, wine; the third, a woman. But the truth is the strongest of all.
At nightfall Abraham worships a star, then the moon which outshines it, & in the morning the sun. Finally he learns to pray only to God.

Classifications: Mightiest Being as Husband for the Daughter
Variation Example: A magician rescues a mouse (rat) which he transforms into a girl. Or, a childless couple wish for a child but instead have a mouse. The magician (parents) thinks the girl is the most beautiful creature in the world & wants to marry her to the mightiest husband. They ask the moon, who refuses & says the sun is brighter than he. The sun refuses because the clouds cover him. The clouds say the wind blows them. The wind says the mountain (castle) stops him. The mountain says a mouse digs inside him. The mouse is therefore the mightiest & becomes the daughter’s husband.

An animal (mouse) is wounded (by another animal) & asks for help. He is told that this will happen only if he brings a particular object (fulfills some other request). The injured animal has to ask someone else for this object. This develops into a chain of demands & counter-requests, until finally someone (thing) agrees without a counter-request. The animal is treated for his injury, or else he dies before all the requests are granted. In Spanish & Portuguese variants, a toad asks a magpie to throw something (a nut) down from a tree. The magpie is afraid its beak will break, but the toad promises to repair it. The beak breaks & the toad goes after horsehair to mend it. He is sent to fulfill other requests, until finally someone does not make a counter-request. Everyone in the chain gets what he or she wanted, & finally the toad brings the horsehair to the magpie .

A hunting cat bites off a mouse’s tail. Or, a woman cuts the tail off (belly open) of a mouse (cat, rat) because it stole her milk. The mouse wants to get its tail back. The mouse asks the cat for its tail (the cobbler to sew its belly), but is told it must do something (e.g. bring milk from the goat or cow). The goat wants the mouse to give it grass, the meadow wants water, the well wants eggs, the chicken wants corn, etc. Finally someone complies & all the rest get what they want. Or, the mouse is eaten.

This chain tale leads step by step to the following conclusion: This is the farmer that sowed the corn, that kept the rooster that crowed in the morn, that waked the priest all shaven & shorn, that married the man all tattered & torn, that kissed the maiden all forlorn, that milked the cow with a crumpled horn, that tossed the dog, that worried the cat, that caught the rat, that ate the malt that lay in the house that Jack built.

Classifications: A Drop of Honey Causes Chain of Accidents
Variation Example: A hunter is about to buy some honey, but he drops it. A weasel eats the honey & is chased by a cat. The hunter’s dog kills the cat, & the grocer beats the dog to death. This causes a bloody war between two villages.

A merchant on his way home stays at an inn & someone tells him that one of the nails is missing from one of his horse’s shoes. At the next inn the shoe has fallen off. Nevertheless, the merchant rides on. The horse becomes lame, stumbles, & breaks a leg. The merchant has to carry his goods himself & go home on foot. In some variants the horse of a soldier loses a horse shoe, & in the end a battle & a kingdom are lost.

A man who has been away for a long time asks an acquaintance for news from home. The acquaintance tells him that his dog (raven) is dead. The man asks why, & is told that it ate too much horse (camel) flesh. The horse had been burned in its stall (died from exertion during a fire); the barn caught fire from the house; the fire had been started by candles in the house; the candles burned on the occasion of the death of the man’s mother (wife).

A man catches a bird eating mangoes & strikes it against the roots of a mango tree. The bird says that it was not hurt. In turn, the man puts it in water, strikes it again, singes its feathers, cooks it, & eats it. The bird always says that it was not hurt. At last the bird flies out of the man’s nose (and the man dies).
This misc. type consists of various chain tales in which a minor incident (insect sting, snakebite) causes a series of other events leading to someone’s death (loss of valuable property).

This misc. type consists of various chain tales in which an animal is injured by another animal (accidentally or on purpose). The injury causes a series of accidents in which other animals are injured. At the end, a high-ranking animal (person) investi gates the matter & discovers all that has happened

A game, song, or rhyme composed of questions & answers that lead to the next question. For example, “Where is the warehouse (God’s house)?” – “The fire burned it.” – “Where is the fire?” – “The water quenched it.” – “Where is the water?” etc.

A man attempts to pull up a turnip. He cannot do it alone, so he calls his wife to help him: she pulls on him, he pulls the turnip, but still the turnip will not come out of the ground. More people & animals are brought in to help. At the end, a long line of helpers pulls on the turnip & it comes out of the ground
Misc. type. The manner of telling forces a listener to ask a particular question (to complete something that is mis-sing). The narrator gives him a ridiculous (obscene) answer

Classifications: Teller is Killed in His Own Tale
Variation Example: The narrator relates a dramatic event that supposedly happened to himself. The listener is induced to ask a question about what happened further, to which the narrator replies that he was killed

A man in a train smokes a cigar (pipe), which falls out of the train. His dog jumps out after it, & is waiting at the next station when the train arrives there. “What do you think he had in his mouth?” – “The cigar?” – “No, his tongue.”

Three girls find three coins & use them to buy three pigs, named Lean, Fat, & Tail. They call their pigs: “Come here, Lean!” – “I can’t, I am too lean.” – “Come here, Fat!” – “I can’t, I am too fat.” – “Come here...” to the listener, “What was the third one called?” – “Tail” – “Lift your tail.” (Another answer that depends on double-entendre.)
Misc. type. The narrator tells about some-one who has found something, but stops just as the tale gets interesting. “If the found object had been longer, so would my tale.”

When he dies, the king leaves a great mountain to his three sons. They dig into it & find a big iron box with a frying pan inside it, & a little rabbit under that. The rabbit has only a stump for a tail. If his tail had been longer, so would this tale.

A boy finds a little box & keeps it. Later he finds a little key. He discovers that the key fits the lock on the box. When he opens the box, he finds a calf’s tail (mouse’s tail, fur) inside. If the tail had been longer, so would this tale. (Or, he opens the box but what he finds there will be told another time.)

Misc. type. When children annoy their parents by persistently demanding a story, the latter retaliate by telling a brief “mock story”. For example, the parents tell about people (animals), of whom the third is named Enough (Stop). The parents ask the child what the name of the third person was. When the child answers, “Enough”, the parents end the tale

The narrator asks the listeners a question & ex pects a particular answer. The dialog continues until the answer is given. For example, “I’ll tell you the story about the green pig? Shall I?” – “You should.” – “I didn’t say you should. I’ll tell you the story about the green pig”, etc.

Misc. type. The narrator reports on something that takes a long time & says that he will continue the tale when it is com pleted. The following is the most common version: a shepherd has to take many sheep over a bridge, which is so narrow that they have to pass over one at a time. The listeners have to wait while each sheep crosses the bridge to the other side

Classifications: Corn Carried Away One Grain at a Time
Variation Example: A master rich farmer promises his daughter in marriage to whoever can tell a tale without an end. Many suitors try & fail & are put to death. One young man says, “A farmer harvested a large amount of grain. While he congratulated himself on his success, a mouse came & took a grain of wheat. The next day, another mouse comes & takes a grain of wheat. The next day...” etc. The master loses patience & lets the narrator marry his daughter.

Classifications: The Crow on the Tarred Bridge
Variation Example: Endless tale about a crow whose beak & tail alternately stick to the tar on a bridge
Misc. type with diverse variants.
